UAL1TY

HOP

ORGANIZED ALUMNI BODIES
Within the past two months the Triangle Club of Princeton, the
Dartmouth Musical Club and the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club have
appeared before the Baltimore public during the course of a tour
which included, in its itinerary, the largest cities of the East and
South.
To those interested in Hopkins activities the question naturally
arises: "Why can't the Hopkins Dramatic Club and Musical Clubs
undertake such tours?" One need not seek long before he discovers
the answer to this query. Hopkins organizations cannot attempt an
extended tour because outside of the city of Baltimore the institution
has no organized alumni support.

Cake Eater

And alumni support is essential in an undertaking of this kind.
A hall must be procured, widespread publicity must be obtained,
tickets must be sold and hundreds of other incidentals, which only an
interested body can take care of, must be attended to.

—model of1900

There are divers other ways in which active alumni bodies, organized in the larger cities, could serve their Alma Mater. They could
make possible longer trips for the athletic teams, they could "tall:
Hopkins" to desirable preparatory material in their district and could
advertise the University in numerous ways. In fact, there is no limit
to the aid which organized and enthusiastic groups of graduates could
render to Hopkins.
If June Week does nothing except to bring a large number of
alumni back to Hopkins and instil in them permanent enthusiasm
which will result in the formation of such bodies, the occasion will
be a distinct success.
GO TO IT!
While the great world without goes on unconcernedly with its
work, unaware that great and important events are pending, an undercurrent of excitement pervades the Hopkins campus. Frequent secret
meetings are held at which doors and windows are zealously policed
to prevent intrusion. Undergraduates gather in select groups, put
their heads together in whispered conversation and appear to be
discussing problems of enormous significance. An air of secrecy, of
mystery, of restrained expectancy, permeates the atmosphere.
Such behavior naturally elicits doubts and misgivings from the
unitiated. To the undergraduate, however, these symptoms merely
appear as an indication that banquet season, famed in Hopkins traditions, is about to open. While the apparently dignified Seniors and
Juniors look on with ill-concealed jealousy, the Freshmen and Sophomores formulate carefully guarded plans in which the terms "kidnapping," "class officers" and "suburbs" figure to a great extent.
Go to it, men! Class banquets constitute one of Hopkins' most
valued traditions. You will retain memories of accompanying events
long after Calculus and Greek, Physics and History have departed
from even the sub-conscious mind. Remember, however, to temper
your enthusiasm with a certain amount of caution. Faculty members
and city authorities do not view these matters with the same eyes as
do undergraduates.
We are not advocating violence, but—again—go to it!

He was called dude and dandy
then, but you recognize the type.
He majored in haberdashery and
took his degree with honors in
soxology.
As if that were not enough, he
evolved some variations on the cake
walk which made them stare.
He even found time to develop a
remarkable proficiency on the tandem
bicycle, and on Saturday nights he
was good enough to bring pleasure
into Another's life by wheeling away
to the "Ten-Twent-Thirt."
To crowd all this into four short
years would seem enough for any.
mortal. Yet in spite of his attainments there are times, in after life,
when our hero wonders.
The glory of his waistcoats has
long since faded, while his books are
still fresh and clean. Did he perchance
put too much thought into the selection of his hats and too little in what
went under them?

HOP

ORGANIZED ALUMNI BODIES
Within the past two months the Triangle Club of Princeton, the
Dartmouth Musical Club and the Harvard Hasty Pudding Club have
appeared before the Baltimore public during the course of a tour
which included, in its itinerary, the largest cities of the East and
South.
To those interested in Hopkins activities the question naturally
arises: "Why can't the Hopkins Dramatic Club and Musical Clubs
undertake such tours?" One need not seek long before he discovers
the answer to this query. Hopkins organizations cannot attempt an
extended tour because outside of the city of Baltimore the institution
has no organized alumni support.

Cake Eater

And alumni support is essential in an undertaking of this kind.
A hall must be procured, widespread publicity must be obtained,
tickets must be sold and hundreds of other incidentals, which only an
interested body can take care of, must be attended to.

—model of1900

There are divers other ways in which active alumni bodies, organized in the larger cities, could serve their Alma Mater. They could
make possible longer trips for the athletic teams, they could "tall:
Hopkins" to desirable preparatory material in their district and could
advertise the University in numerous ways. In fact, there is no limit
to the aid which organized and enthusiastic groups of graduates could
render to Hopkins.
If June Week does nothing except to bring a large number of
alumni back to Hopkins and instil in them permanent enthusiasm
which will result in the formation of such bodies, the occasion will
be a distinct success.
GO TO IT!
While the great world without goes on unconcernedly with its
work, unaware that great and important events are pending, an undercurrent of excitement pervades the Hopkins campus. Frequent secret
meetings are held at which doors and windows are zealously policed
to prevent intrusion. Undergraduates gather in select groups, put
their heads together in whispered conversation and appear to be
discussing problems of enormous significance. An air of secrecy, of
mystery, of restrained expectancy, permeates the atmosphere.
Such behavior naturally elicits doubts and misgivings from the
unitiated. To the undergraduate, however, these symptoms merely
appear as an indication that banquet season, famed in Hopkins traditions, is about to open. While the apparently dignified Seniors and
Juniors look on with ill-concealed jealousy, the Freshmen and Sophomores formulate carefully guarded plans in which the terms "kidnapping," "class officers" and "suburbs" figure to a great extent.
Go to it, men! Class banquets constitute one of Hopkins' most
valued traditions. You will retain memories of accompanying events
long after Calculus and Greek, Physics and History have departed
from even the sub-conscious mind. Remember, however, to temper
your enthusiasm with a certain amount of caution. Faculty members
and city authorities do not view these matters with the same eyes as
do undergraduates.
We are not advocating violence, but—again—go to it!

He was called dude and dandy
then, but you recognize the type.
He majored in haberdashery and
took his degree with honors in
soxology.
As if that were not enough, he
evolved some variations on the cake
walk which made them stare.
He even found time to develop a
remarkable proficiency on the tandem
bicycle, and on Saturday nights he
was good enough to bring pleasure
into Another's life by wheeling away
to the "Ten-Twent-Thirt."
To crowd all this into four short
years would seem enough for any.
mortal. Yet in spite of his attainments there are times, in after life,
when our hero wonders.
The glory of his waistcoats has
long since faded, while his books are
still fresh and clean. Did he perchance
put too much thought into the selection of his hats and too little in what
went under them?
